image.altText: A burned out car with people around it in rescue gear late at night

items.synopsis: Hezbollah says "the enemy will pay the price" after an air strike, which Israel says was targeting terrorists, killed three children. While Jordan's king confirms a midnight aid air-drop. Follow live

title.children: Hezbollah says Israel to 'pay price' for Lebanon strike as Jordan airdrops aid in Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Jordan's King Abdullah says Jordan's air force personnel have "air-dropped at midnight urgent medical aid to the Jordanian field hospital in Gaza". He said it is Jordan's duty and that it would always stand with Palestinians. "A royal air force plane dropped urgent medical aid using parachutes to the Jordanian field hospital in Gaza whose supplies were about to run out due to the delay of delivering aid through Rafah crossing", Jordan's state news agency said citing a military source in the General Command of the Jordanian Armed Forces. After signing a peace treaty 30 years ago, Jordan and Israel have had a good political relationship, however with the current escalation the government has faced pressure to not only express their solidarity with Palestinians, but to take action. The King and Queen have criticised Israel's actions in Gaza and called for an immediate cease fire and Jordan's ambassador was recalled while the Israeli ambassador was told to stay away. You can read more about the challenges Jordan now faces here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jordan King: Air force airdropped urgent medical aid in Gaza

featuredLink.title: Why an 'extraordinary' statement by Queen Rania was the first sign of shifting priorities in Jordan

children.content: Jordan's King Abdullah says Jordan's air force personnel have "air-dropped at midnight urgent medical aid to the Jordanian field hospital in Gaza".
He said it is Jordan's duty and that it would always stand with Palestinians.

"A royal air force plane dropped urgent medical aid using parachutes to the Jordanian field hospital in Gaza whose supplies were about to run out due to the delay of delivering aid through Rafah crossing", Jordan's state news agency said citing a military source in the General Command of the Jordanian Armed Forces.

After signing a peace treaty 30 years ago, Jordan and Israel have had a good political relationship, however with the current escalation the government has faced pressure to not only express their solidarity with Palestinians, but to take action.
The King and Queen have criticised Israel's actions in Gaza and called for an immediate cease fire and Jordan's ambassador was recalled while the Israeli ambassador was told to stay away.
You can read more about the challenges Jordan now faces here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Earlier we reported that Lebanese authorities said an Israeli strike on a car in south Lebanon killed three children and their grandmother. Now in a statement, Hezbollah said it would never tolerate attacks on civilians and its response would be "firm and strong". "The enemy will pay the price for its crimes against civilians," Hezbollah lawmaker Hassan Fadlallah told Reuters. Footage broadcast by television station al-Mayadeen showed rescue workers removing one of the casualties from the still-smouldering remains of the car. Israel's military said its troops engaged a vehicle "identified as a suspected transport for terrorists" in Lebanon, and it was looking into reports there were civilians inside. Lebanon's caretaker Prime Minister Najib Mikati called it a "heinous crime." Foreign Minister Abdallah Bou Habib told Reuters Lebanon would submit a complaint to the United Nations over the killing of civilians, including children, in the attack. For a deeper dive into the history of Hezbollah, Matt Bevan takes a look at how they were created: Or you can read our explainer here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hezbollah says Israel to 'pay price' after strike kills 3 children in Lebanon

featuredLink.title: What is Hezbollah and what happens if it gets involved in the Israel-Hamas conflict?

mediaThumbnail.caption:
While Israel tries to defeat Hamas, they also have to worry about a much more dangerous paramilitary group on their northern border: Hezbollah. The express purpose of Hezbollah, which formed 40 years ago, is also to eradicate Israel. So where did Hezbollah form? Why do they hate Israel, and what hand did Israel have in their creation?
Matt Bevan takes a look.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has appeared to backtrack on a comment he was reported to have made earlier about the need to check if a pre-war protest among army reservists pushed Hamas to carry out its attack last month. Israel's Channel 12 and other news outlets reported that Mr Netanyahu said there may be a need to examine whether months of protests against his government, including by reservists who said they would no longer report for regular duty, added to Hamas' motivation to carry out the October 7 rampage through southern Israel that triggered the current war. Benny Gantz, who joined Netanyahu's war cabinet from the opposition as part of an emergency government, said Mr Netanyahu must retract his comment. "Avoiding responsibility and slinging mud at the time of war is a blow to the country," Mr Gantz wrote on social media platform X. After the public backlash, Mr Netanyahu posted on X that Hamas started a war "because it wants to kill us all and not because of any argument within us ." On Saturday, protesters gathered outside Netanyahu's residence, chanting "Jail Now!" in a public display of anger at the failures that led to the arrack. The protest, which coincided with a poll showing more than three-quarters of Israelis believe Mr Netanyahu should resign, underlined the growing public fury at their political and security leaders.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli PM Benjamin  Netanyahu backtracks on reported comment linking Hamas attack to reservist protest

children.content: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has appeared to backtrack on a comment he was reported to have made earlier about the need to check if a pre-war protest among army reservists pushed Hamas to carry out its attack last month.
Israel's Channel 12 and other news outlets reported that Mr Netanyahu said
there may be a need to examine whether months of protests against his government, including by reservists who said they would no longer report for regular duty, added to Hamas' motivation
to carry out the October 7 rampage through southern Israel that triggered the current war.
Benny Gantz, who joined Netanyahu's war cabinet from the opposition as part of an emergency government, said Mr Netanyahu must retract his comment.
"Avoiding responsibility and slinging mud at the time of war is a blow to the country,"
Mr Gantz wrote on social media platform X.
After the public backlash, Mr Netanyahu posted on X that
Hamas started a war "because it wants to kill us all and not because of any argument within us
On Saturday, protesters gathered outside Netanyahu's residence, chanting "Jail Now!" in a public display of anger at the failures that led to the arrack.
The protest, which coincided with a poll showing more than three-quarters of Israelis believe Mr Netanyahu should resign, underlined the growing public fury at their political and security leaders.

image.altText: A Westpac sign with 24/7 banking.

items.synopsis: The ASX rises after Wall Street's surge on worse-than-expected US jobs numbers, further lowering the prospect of more interest rate hikes. Westpac posts a 26 per cent jump in profit and a $1.5 billion share buyback. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX rises amid Westpac profit surge and CSL rebound, Wall St up on weaker economic news

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Overall, not much changed over the past couple of hours since the ASX opened. The benchmark ASX 200 index is 0.3% higher at 7,000 points, bang in line with where the futures were trading this morning. Healthcare continues to lead gains, although Resmed (+3.5%) has pulled ahead of CSL (+1.4%) as the preferred stock in the sector. Aged care operator Regis Healthcare is the absolute standout, up more than 5% to $2.70. The big banks are all doing well on the back of Westpac's 26% surge in full-year profit, with investors no doubt hoping for similar returns from the other two big banks soon to report — ANZ and NAB. Westpac itself surged 3.6% to $22.27 after also announcing a $1.5 billion share buyback. I listened in to the bank's analyst/media briefing and will have a post on some highlights from that shortly. Elsewhere on the market, gold miners were popular, filling up much of the top movers list. But while precious metals were in vogue, base ones were just that today, with big operators like BHP (-1.1%), Rio Tinto (-1.1%) and South32 (-1.8%) all down. Biggest gains: Iress Ltd +8.3% to $5.64 De Grey Mining +6.3% to $1.2175 Evolution Mining +6% to $3.72 Star Entertainment Group +4.9% to $0.5875 Genesis Minerals +4.7% to $1.5125 Biggest losses: Block -5.1% to $77.05 Paladin Energy -5% to $0.955 Coronado Global Resources -3% to $1.7025 Computershare -2.3% to $24.55 Karoon Energy -2.2% to $2.465
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX holds gains to lunch, gold miners up, other miners down, healthcare and banks lead

children.content: Overall, not much changed over the past couple of hours since the ASX opened.
The benchmark
ASX 200 index is 0.3% higher at 7,000 points
, bang in line with where the futures were trading this morning.
Healthcare continues to lead gains, although
Resmed (+3.5%) has pulled ahead of CSL (+1.4%)
as the preferred stock in the sector.
Aged care operator
Regis Healthcare
is the absolute standout, up more than 5% to $2.70.
The big banks are all doing well on the back of Westpac's 26% surge in full-year profit, with investors no doubt hoping for similar returns from the other two big banks soon to report — ANZ and NAB.
Westpac itself surged 3.6% to $22.27
after also announcing a $1.5 billion share buyback.
I listened in to the bank's analyst/media briefing and will have a post on some highlights from that shortly.
Elsewhere on the market,
gold miners were popular
, filling up much of the top movers list.
But while precious metals were in vogue, base ones were just that today, with big operators like
BHP (-1.1%), Rio Tinto (-1.1%) and South32 (-1.8%)
all down.
Biggest gains:
Iress Ltd +8.3% to $5.64
De Grey Mining +6.3% to $1.2175
Evolution Mining +6% to $3.72
Star Entertainment Group +4.9% to $0.5875
Genesis Minerals +4.7% to $1.5125
Biggest losses:
Paladin Energy -5% to $0.955
Coronado Global Resources -3% to $1.7025
Computershare -2.3% to $24.55
Karoon Energy -2.2% to $2.465

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A former Qantas executive says he's surprised the airline's board survived last Friday's annual general meeting. While new CEO Vanessa Hudson promised to restore public trust in Qantas, 83% of shareholders voted against the airline's remuneration report — delivering one of the biggest protest votes in Australian corporate history, and putting the whole of the Qantas board on notice. Aviation consultant and former chief legal officer for Qantas, Andrew Charlton, says that should have prompted a change of management. "What I found even more remarkable was that the board didn't automatically fall on their swords at that point," he said. "I would have thought that was the only appropriate response. "But they insist they know what they're doing better than anybody else, and they intend to carry on." If you missed the fallout from Qantas' annual general meeting last Friday, my colleague business reporter Nassim Khadem has you covered:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former Qantas exec says it's 'remarkable' board didn't 'fall on their swords' after AGM

children.content: A former Qantas executive says he's surprised the airline's board survived last Friday's annual general meeting.
While new CEO Vanessa Hudson promised to restore public trust in Qantas,
83% of shareholders voted against the airline's remuneration report
— delivering
one of the biggest protest votes in Australian corporate history
, and putting the whole of the Qantas board on notice.
Aviation consultant and former chief legal officer for Qantas,
Andrew Charlton
, says that should have prompted a change of management.
"What I found even more remarkable was that the board didn't automatically fall on their swords at that point," he said.
"I would have thought that was the only appropriate response.
"But they insist they know what they're doing better than anybody else, and they intend to carry on."
If you missed the fallout from Qantas' annual general meeting last Friday, my colleague
business reporter Nassim Khadem
has you covered:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX is posting modest gains, with the benchmark indices both up around a third of a per cent in the first 15 minutes of trade. Gains were fairly broad based, with 136 of the ASX 200 companies on the rise and only 51 down. Healthcare was the standout, up 1.5%, with CSL jumping 2.1% to $249.20 and Resmed up 2.9% to $23.83, in part due to positive comments from an investment manager in the Australian Financial Review (paywalled). Education (1.1%), Utilities (0.8%) and Consumer Cyclicals (0.8%) were also strongly on the up. On the flip side, Industrials (1.6%), Energy (0.8%) and Basic Materials, which is mainly mining (0.3%), were the sectors losing ground. Biggest gains: Weebit Nano +10% to $4.29 Neuren Pharmaceuticals +5.8% to $12.96 Iress Ltd +5.6% to $5.50 West African Resources +5% to $0.835 Ramelius Resources +5% to $1.695 Biggest losses: Block -5.8% to $76.49 Coronado Global Resources - 3.1% to $1.70 Paladin Energy -3% to $0.975 Karoon Energy -1.8% to $2.475 Computershare Ltd -1.6% to $24.72
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Healthcare and utilities lead ASX higher, while miners, energy and industrials weigh
